node.title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
node.alt: Lili Bernard in a scene from “We Need to Talk About Cosby.”
node.description: W. Kamau Bell takes account of Bill Cosby. And Jonathan Van Ness takes a journey through his passions.
node.content: ["\u2018We Need to Talk About Cosby\u2019When to Watch: Sunday at 10 p.m., on Showtime.", "In the first hour of this four-part documentary, the comedian W. Kamau Bell interrogates the legacy of Bill Cosby, \u201cAmerica\u2019s Dad,\u201d who became \u201cAmerica\u2019s Dad Accused of a Pattern of Serial Drugging and Rape.\u201d (His 2018 conviction on three counts of aggravated indecent assault was overturned in 2021.) Using archival footage, clips from Cosby\u2019s comedy albums, talking-head interviews and testimony from several of his more than 50 accusers, Bell begins to unpack Cosby\u2019s complicated cultural standing. Or, as he puts it, \u201cWhat do we do about everything we knew about Bill Cosby and what we know now?\u201d", "\u2018The Afterparty\u2019When to Watch: Beginning Friday, on AppleTV+.", "\u201cNothing can ruin this night!\u201d a man says of his 15-year high school reunion. Then a dead body plummets to the beach below. The first three episodes of this murder mystery comedy arrive Friday, with five to come. The shtick? Each episode embodies a different cinematic style. (Does this story really need eight episodes? Are the generic lampoons successful? You decide!)", "But the casting department has outdone itself, with an ensemble that includes Tiffany Haddish as the lead investigator, alongside Zo\u00eb Chao, John Early, Dave Franco, Ilana Glazer and Sam Richardson. If the mystery itself palls, you can always luxuriate in Haddish and her one-liners. \u201cGet the cornstarch,\u201d she tells Early\u2019s junior detective. \u201cThe plot thickens.\u201d Here\u2019s the real mystery: Does anyone actually look forward to high school reunions?", "\u2018Getting Curious With Jonathan Van Ness\u2019When to Watch: Arrives Friday, on Netflix.", "Have you ever wished that John Wilson had better hair? Or that David Attenborough sometimes sang? Then please enjoy this eclectic documentary series from Jonathan Van Ness, the grooming expert of \u201cQueer Eye.\u201d Inspired by Van Ness\u2019s podcast of the same name, this six-episode series finds him indulging his passions (hair care, snacks, ice skating, unmaking the gender binary) and investigating the occasional not-so-burning question (How are skyscrapers built? Do insects taste nice?) His investigations are not especially rigorous. But his enthusiasm feels genuine. And his hair? Perfection."]
